<h1 id="intro" class="docs-title scia-typo-uppercase scia-typo-normal scia-typo-black">Themes</h1>

<p class="intro">
Scia CSS uses a **token-based theme system** built around color roles instead of raw colors.
The same roles are reused across components, utilities, and custom UI, allowing consistent
light, dark, and system-driven themes.
</p>

<br/>
---


<h2 id="theme-modes" class="scia-h2 docs-subtitle">Theme modes</h2>

Scia CSS supports three theme modes:

- **Auto (default)**: follows the system preference
- **Light**
- **Dark**

### Force a theme

Set the `data-scia-theme` attribute on the root element:

```html
<html data-scia-theme="light">...</html>
<html data-scia-theme="dark">...</html>
```

<div class="scia-blockquote-warning">
<span class="blockquote-paragraph">If you omit it, Scia CSS can follow the system theme (depending on your implementation).</span>
</div>

<br/>
---

<h2 id="color-roles" class="scia-h2 docs-subtitle">Color roles</h2>

Instead of naming colors like “blue-500”, Scia CSS uses **roles**.
Roles describe purpose, not hue. Below all the scia themes roles.

<br/>

### Core roles
| Role                     | Description                              |
| :-- | :-- |
| <code class="scia-code">--scia-color-bg</code>        | Page background color                    |
| <code class="scia-code">--scia-color-surface</code>   | Background for cards, panels, and blocks |
| <code class="scia-code">--scia-color-text</code>      | Primary text color                       |
| <code class="scia-code">--scia-color-text-muted</code> | Secondary / muted text                   |
| <code class="scia-code">--scia-color-border</code>    | Default border color                     |


<br/>

### Brand roles
| Role                            | Description                              |
| :-- | :-- |
| <code class="scia-code">--scia-color-primary</code>          | Primary brand/action color               |
| <code class="scia-code">--scia-color-primary-soft</code>     | Subtle background for primary accents    |
| <code class="scia-code">--scia-color-primary-strong</code>   | Emphasis / hover / active variant        |
| <code class="scia-code">--scia-color-on-primary</code>       | Text/icon color on primary backgrounds   |
| <code class="scia-code">--scia-color-secondary</code>        | Secondary accent color                   |
| <code class="scia-code">--scia-color-secondary-soft</code>   | Subtle secondary background              |
| <code class="scia-code">--scia-color-secondary-strong</code> | Emphasis variant                         |
| <code class="scia-code">--scia-color-on-secondary</code>     | Text/icon color on secondary backgrounds |


<br/>

### Status roles
| Role                        | Description          |
| :-- | :-- |
| <code class="scia-code">--scia-color-success</code>      | Success state        |
| <code class="scia-code">--scia-color-success-soft</code> | Success background   |
| <code class="scia-code">--scia-color-warning</code>      | Warning state        |
| <code class="scia-code">--scia-color-warning-soft</code> | Warning background   |
| <code class="scia-code">--scia-color-danger</code>       | Error / danger state |
| <code class="scia-code">--scia-color-danger-soft</code>  | Danger background    |
| <code class="scia-code">--scia-color-info</code>         | Informational state  |
| <code class="scia-code">--scia-color-info-soft</code>    | Info background      |


<div class="scia-blockquote-warning">
<span class="blockquote-paragraph">The exact variable names depend on your Scia CSS tokens file — keep your docs aligned with your real variables.</span>
</div>

<br/>
---


<h2 id="theme-structure" class="scia-h2 docs-subtitle">Theme structure</h2>

Scia CSS can work in three modes:

1. **Default (Light)** when no theme attribute is set
2. **Manual Light/Dark** when <code class="scia-code">data-scia-theme</code> is explicitly set
3. **Auto-Dark** when the user’s system preference is dark **and** no manual theme was chosen

If you want to **keep Auto mode** and still override the palette, you should mirror the full structure below.

<br/>

### Example of overwrite while maintaining Auto mode

```css
/* 1) Default: Light theme (applies when no manual theme is selected) */
:root {
    /* override your Scia tokens here (light defaults) */
    --scia-color-bg: #ffffff;
    --scia-color-surface: #f8fafc;
    --scia-color-text: #0f172a;
    ...
}

/* 2) Manual Light mode (wins over everything when explicitly set) */
:root[data-scia-theme="light"] {
    /* optional: only needed if you want manual-light to differ from :root */
    --scia-color-bg: #ffffff;
    --scia-color-surface: #f8fafc;
    --scia-color-text: #0f172a;
    ...
}

/* 3) Manual Dark mode (wins over everything when explicitly set) */
:root[data-scia-theme="dark"] {
    --scia-color-bg: #0b1220;
    --scia-color-surface: #111a2b;
    --scia-color-text: #e5e7eb;
    ...
}

/* 4) Auto-Dark:
   if the user prefers dark at OS level AND data-scia-theme is NOT set */
@media (prefers-color-scheme: dark) {
  :root:not([data-scia-theme]) {
    /* usually matches the same values as manual dark */
    --scia-color-bg: #0b1220;
    --scia-color-surface: #111a2b;
    --scia-color-text: #e5e7eb;
    ...
  }
}
```

<br/>

### Why this structure?
- <code class="scia-code">:root</code> defines the default palette (commonly light).
- <code class="scia-code">:root[data-scia-theme="light"]</code> and <code class="scia-code">:root[data-scia-theme="dark"]</code> define manual overrides.
- The <code class="scia-code">@media (prefers-color-scheme: dark)</code> rule only applies when no manual theme is selected, thanks to <code class="scia-code">:root:not([data-scia-theme])</code>.

This gives you:
- a reliable default
- a manual switch option
- automatic system-based dark mode without extra JavaScript


<br/>

### Overriding only one mode (optional)
If your project does **not** need Auto mode, you can override only the theme you use:

- **Light-only project:** override <code class="scia-code">:root</code> (and optionally <code class="scia-code">:root[data-scia-theme="light"]</code>)
- **Dark-only project:** override <code class="scia-code">:root[data-scia-theme="dark"]</code> (or set the attribute permanently)
